pros: Management at the North Jersey location was great! A lot of good people there. The environment was relaxed and would pick up whenever certain deadlines became tight. Design Assistants don't get a lot of reach, but it's a good stepping stone for people in the Industrial Design industry to get first hand knowledge of packaging in POP design. Especially for college students.
cons: There was favoritism between certain Senior Designers among the Design Assistants. It was a very weird thing. You're there to help all the designers, but then certain designers don't want your help and only look for certain Assistants to help them which means that you never get to learn how to do certain tasks (you help Graphic Designers and Structural Designers in this role), then suddenly when that assistant isn't available to them, they get annoyed with you when you were never shown how to complete a particular task. There is very little opportunity for growth as well. You'd be lucky if they hired you full- time within 2 years. I've seen two lay-offs happen while there. The layoffs are a result of it being a large company and not due to the managers. The company constantly monitors employee output, so they lay people off yearly to give it a scrub. That's probably the worst part of it.

pros: Running water Flush toilets Free protection
cons: Currently, it's probably one of the most toxic workplaces in Canada. Nevermind the broken machinery. Back breaking labor. Extreme heat. Tyrannical rule and unethical behavior from management. I could go on and on

review_title: They don't really seem to care about employees...

cons: Only one week of vacation starting out as long as you have the working hours to qualify They will not take care of you if you become disabled from a disease. Low work life balance. Long shifts (16+ hours) for shutdowns. No frilly holidays, just the bare minimum ones, or personal days. It's a paper mill so it's old and there are lots of dangerous places, they are 'concerned' about safety, so it's unlikely you'll get injured. Especially if you're cautious. Everyone looks out fir each other though. There are lots of freezing cold and rainy days you'll be working outside all day, but they do provide you with good equipment to weather the storm, if you will.

review_title: DOES NOT CARE ABOUT EMPLOYEES  HERES PROOF
job_title: Operator Assistant in Niagara Falls, NY
pros: Decent pay. (Not worth it)
cons: I worked at this job personally for 6 months before quitting (it doesn’t get better). If you work your 8 hours and the the next shift person to relieve you doesn’t come in you’re forced to stay an additional 4 hours without warning! Wether you have kids or priorities at home and can’t stay, they do not care. If you leave it’s “job abandonment” and they take it as “you quit.“ They tell you in your interview “you’ll work a couple Saturdays here and there.” But it’s a lie. Your schedule is Monday through Friday, off Saturday, Sunday (set schedule). They force you every single week to work Saturday over time so the big bosses can earn bonuses. No profit share, no bonus check, nothing for your performance. They told us in a meeting “we made $80 million in profit last year , thank you!” “Now we want you to double it!” That’s with working 6 days a week 4 days off a month. This places doesn’t care about its employees they hire a group of 7 every other month because they can’t stay staffed/ to replace you.

pros: Quiet, heads down work environment.

pros: Enjoyable work atmosphere, great learning experience, work life balance.
cons: Not much room for growth.

pros:
I started WestRock @ $20/hr and resigned at $28/hr when I was on a paper shipping conveyor operator bid. You must have a thick skin working here and the only decent people that work at WestRock are the operators, foremen and papermakers themselves. 

If you plan on working here, everybody does each job different so learn your own way and pick the best techniques everyone shows you, that's how you'll get proficient. Papermaking is difficult to learn but easy to do, so the money is worth it.
cons:
EQUIPMENT IS NEVER MAINTAINED DUE TO MANAGEMENT INCOMPETENCE. That's a very important one if you want to work for WestRock, this in itself creates safety issues.

The company talks safety as priority, when production is actually priority. The union is nothing but clout, they will talk big talk about representing you but they're just in it for the extra paycheck. I got denied by Sedgwick (WestRock's choice of private worker's insurance) for some unpaid FMLA for only a week to take care of my mom. WestRock incorporates an accident liability program called SafeStart, which is basically the cards stacked against the worker; either you were rushing or you were complacent, either way it's your fault. Every system that is designed to help the worker at WestRock actually condemns them.
I was only at the Tacoma Mill for 3 years, but a coworker who had been there 35+ years said it was being run the worst he had ever seen it; that's because WestRock took over the Tacoma Mill after Simpson.

Just more BS to tolerate than necessary.

cons:
Only speaking for Westrock 2300 International Pkwy, Woodridge IL.

Very strange employee turnover. The large temporary workforce (3rd party) had many associates with 5-7 years experience. To me, that's not "temporary". Why would the company not hire these associates, with company's own climbing turnover rate and the need for direct hires? Something didnt seem quite right, there.

Lots of animosity between the long tenured 3rd party temporary employees and the direct hires due to pay & benefit differences. Management typically went through the motions and ultimately brushed off poor conduct & policy violations from coworkers. This is a reason their direct hire turnover is so high. If you're a timid individual, this probably isn't the place for you.

Site managers are clueless, a site that consistently produced more cartons than all than all the  other UK sites is the one to be closed and staff made redundant. The site was immaculate, purpose built, machines in good order and good quality of work consistently produced - is closed. Yet just up the M1 in Leicester the ramshackle shanty site with with suspicious figures stays open.

Westrock management have no clue why would you close a purpose built factory with great motorway access and a good history and many many experienced staff in favour of a falling to pieces factory, with dubious accounts, less cartons ran per head and poor access to the M1, also set right in the middle of a residential area. No where to park. 

Work moved to other sites and cartons that was messed up at Leicester and resulted in a customer complaint has been blamed on the Nottingham site! 

Lazy manager off sick and employees friends instead of people with job experience 

Actually!!! No wonder it has shut blind leading the blinder

He is a good ole boy inherited by acquisition. 
This is a company that was declared essential in March 2020 by the US government and continued to make a good profit throughout the year and yet, very quietly laid people off at the end of the year to look good on paper to their investors. What a despicable move to contribute to the Nation's unemployment plight when your business has not been affected.

pros: Due to being a large company, they regularly acquire new technologies and assist their staff in acquiring certifications and licenses.

pros: It's good organization it's little bit late sitting at month closing days..but if your goal is to learn and explore your self and nothing else than it's great to work here. HR policies are best in industries and also offers attractive salary
cons: Job security is totally in your hand.. If you can give your 100℅ of output than you can make your job secured here.

pros: The people who work in the corporate office are kind and helpful. Especially when you're new, I felt super comfortable asking anyone questions.
cons: What they ask of you is nearly impossible to achieve. There aren't enough supply chain analysts to divvy up the work equally. I assume this is because the employee turnover rate is significant. The other analsyts are great to work with but the plant managers can be extremely diffuclt to say the least. At times conversations with the plant managers can get heated. More often than not, problems occur that aren't your fault but you are repeately reminded that it is on you to solve them.

pros:
Career Development: There are many in house training opportunities such as; safety training, black and green belt six sigma training, maintenance, and online training above several specific topics (ranging from pumps, process controls, and how things work). They will pay tuition if you continue your education. 

Operators: Smart, knowledgeable and willing to help you with projects. There is extensive training for operators before they are qualified. I have been impressed with the knowledge and lock-outs.
cons:
Pay: The pay at WR is standard. It may be a little higher at first glance. However, the pay would be decent if you had a standard 40-45 hour work week. The expectation is to work 10 hours a day. They can’t say this, but if you work less than you will be devalued in your yearly review and told you aren’t helping the team. If there are 10 people working on troubleshooting, and you are about to walk out the door you are either faced with 1) stay and work 16 hours and be back in 8 hours, or 2) be devalued because you didn’t stay to help. Management isn’t even concerned about having tired management. Whatever pay is offered, take off 30% of your hourly earnings because an 8 hour day is not possible.

Work-Life Balance: Not recommended if you have a family, friends or any sort of social life. They are workaholics here. It’s expected that you are on call at all times. It doesn’t matter if you’ve worked 16 hours, you are expected to answer calls and come in 8 hours later. Working more than 16 hours is nothing to be proud about and the way people in management brag about working 22 hours is saying “be there or you are not helping the team.” I started with a group of 5 other engineers and those 5 left before me after 2.5 years. 

Career Development: There are many benefits in the pros. Just know that interns get the same trainings offered to you. They'll get things such as team building trips to the theme park and get paid for it. The sad part is that they'll get overtime for doing practically nothing. 

Communication: I hope you like being talked down to and be treated like you don’t know anything in your area of expertise. Lots of people here can never be wrong.

Micro-Management: Not everyone in management is a micro-manager but this comes from the top. This company doesn’t care how much experience you have. They will monitor projects at every step and correct your mistakes. However, if you go by the correction and it doesn't answer the issue several months down the road, the blame will be placed on you. Upper management here does not think they micromanage but they do. They constantly question you for every decision you make. Be ready to know how to answer the 20 questions. Just know that you are not being devalued (at least not yet), it's just the expectation of management to micromanage and answer the 20 questions coming from above.

Decision-making from long term employees: They do not value data that comes off the DCS that you collect. You will need to stand your ground if the data is telling you to do one thing and everyone is telling you "but we've been doing this for 20 years"

pros: I could not have asked for a better experience with my first job out of college. I am a female engineer working at one of MWV's chemical plants. From day one, I was given a large (but reasonable) amount of responsibility. My managers have been great at assigning me to projects that will help me develop as an engineer and figure out what direction I want my career to take. All of my experiences with upper management have been nothing but positive and I truly feel that the company is well prepared for the future in terms of vision and resources. I have held two different positions since starting and have had 2 different managers and teams. The strongest part of MWV, in my opinion, is the people that I work with. This company has so many brilliant and diverse minds in a family environment. My coworkers are supportive and collaborative, not competitive. I am not treated any differently because I am a female, which was one of my main concerns coming out of college. There are many fresh, young faces at MWV, but there are also numerous people who have spent their entire careers with the company. It spoke volumes to me when looking for jobs that this is a company that retains their employees because they truly love what they do and value the culture of MWV.
cons: The biggest problem we have is that there are so many ideas for new products and improvements, but not enough capital funding for major projects. However, there are always a few big projects going on and the company is investing as much as possible to grow our business. The fact that we have so many ideas for growing the company is exciting.

pros: Good pay in all positions. $12-$14/hr. for lowest level positions and as much as $18-$24/hr. for high level machine operators. Also has a great benefit package. All full time employees start off with 2 weeks of paid vacation time that increases up to a maximum of 5 weeks based on time of service. 401k, pension plan, health ins., vision ins., dental ins., short and long term disability if needed.
cons: All of the pros of this job are meaningless because of the environment that management has created. 12 hour shifts. A dysfunctional point system for being late and absences .  There is no teamwork between shifts, all shifts are constantly looking for any and all mistakes made by other shifts in an effort to report the mistake for a "pat on the back". Rules are constantly changing and are never in favor of the hourly employee. Hair nets and beard nets must be worn at all times, even on bald employees. Employee favoritism among management is rampant. Certain employees are allowed to sit on their rear for hours chit chatting with managers and leads while others do all the work. All employees hate working here but hesitate quitting because of the good pay and benefits that we all receive.

review_title: Not a good fit - Questionable senior leadership
pros: Work schedule, challenge, fast paced, good backbone of written safety programs
cons:
Local union only backed safety when it was convenient.  Labor relations was fractured (albeit improving).  Safety programs, initiatives, required training and fundamentals hadn't been touched in over a year.  Regional and corporate safety team talk a good game in Advanced Safety Leadership courses but it isn't the reality of what really goes on under the hood.

Moral and ethical standards aren't very high in that senior level leadership - VPs, area VPs etc. expect "accountability" each and every time a line worker is injured.  Essentially, get hurt, we want someone terminated.  Local leadership can only fight that fight for so long.  Overwhelming focus on "TWCC" KPI - time loss and comp costs.  Overall frontline culture is non-existent to support such granular oversight.  Regional Safety Manager was never really seen and didn't seem to want to do anything other than fly in like a seagull, crap all over the place and fly out.  

Safety office was a joke.  There was a 2 foot hole above the desk chair from a leak well over 4 months.  Lot's of "let's fix it" only to recede to "it's not in the budget".

Local level leaders were good.  They were trying to do the best with what they had.

review_title: Great company with a lot of potential
pros:
WestRock is in a growth mode with focus on expanding core capabilities and service offerings.  Coworkers are great and the company seems vested in developing top talent.  Good pay, travel opportunities and lots of training to expand your skill set.  The Corporate leadership team is forward-thinking, progressive (relative to industry peers), and embraces cultural diversity, treating all employees with respect & dignity.

We are involved in a lot of interesting projects and the work is exciting.  I am very  happy working here and looking forward to the future.
cons:
I have at times witnessed and experienced the typical corporate "Boys Club" vibe...  There are very few women in Senior leadership positions. 

The Company is siloed, often making cross-divisional and even cross-departmental communication challenging.  Frequently there are competing objectives and/or bureaucracy which cripple output and stifle creativity.

Possibly this is limited to my group but the attitudes around flexible working hours/occasional work-from-home seem to be very outdated.  You're treated like a freeloader if you want to work from home more than once a month, even though we travel and put in long hours quite a bit.

cons: Low Pay, Too many work hours, not sure if I can work here again.

review_title: Good corporate vision, but each site runs themselves
pros: Good pay and benefits, good variety of work, good strategy - poor execution, trying to get better just slow
cons:
Outdated equipment, older management style (very tiered), site does not follow corporate visions or policies, each site can choose how and what they do to follow corporate visions and policies there is no unity, Safety is an afterthought many incidents go without reports, Work/life balance is horrible - 7 days straight of 12 hour shifts in the summer and salaried workers work almost every weekend and at least 12 hour days.

As with all manufacturing there is a large focus on cost cutting, but little understanding of how to do it. Many cost cutting involves turning a valve and seeing what happens. This upsets the process many times to some unknown degrees.

review_title: Beatings will continue until morale improves!
pros:
Pays slightly better than welfare.
Free toilet paper.
cons:
Both senior and local management is clueless and is comprised of people without actual management experience.  Local management lacks any sort of knowledge of business process management, conflict resolution skills or even common sense.  The only skill they seem to possess is blind delegation of problems they should be solving at the top.  

There are 2 types of people at MPS. 
The first group of people are bottom of the barrel.  HR brought them in just because they are warm bodies to fill positions at the lowest wage possible.  And yes, there are quite a few of these people that hold management and salaried positions.  They use the “point system” to keep a constant revolving door of hourly workers so they never have to increase anyone's wages or give promotions.    

The second are the real people in charge.  You will know who they are by the bags under their eyes, the 70+ hour work weeks, and the look of complete despair on their faces.  These are the people that are filling 2 to 4 positions at one time.  If they have not quit already.

A warning!!  If you are intelligent, knowledgeable or skilled, expect to be to be driven into the ground.  Overworked and underpaid doesn't even come close to describing it.  Expect 60+ hour weeks at pay well below market value.  Management will pawn off anything they can on you.  

Hourly employees, realize that you will be treated like cattle.  You are considered 100% expendable.

review_title: Really good company with some serious flaws.
pros: Excellent pay. Good people.  Outstanding technology. Capital investment. The company is highly committed to modernizing plants, and backs it up with a lot of capital.  Quality is outstanding.  It is also a very safe place to work; their commitment to safety is absolute.  The commitment to company culture is taken seriously.
cons: Insane hours and crushing workload.  Pays lip service to work/life balance, but doesn't practice what they preach.  12-14 hour days, weekends, no regard for how many hours you have to work and they just keep piling on the work.  You will love the paycheck, but the volume of work keeps you from doing anything really well. The company runs extremely lean, and is top-down hierarchical, dictatorial, so centralized that every day functions are controlled at the corporate level.  Paralysis ensues hindering sales and infuriating customers. Volume is king, and it gets pushed to the point of making very poor short term decisions out of fear of missing budget.  Lastly, job security doesn't exist. They fire people with very little provocation. Depending on local management, second chances are rare.

review_title: Supply Chain- DO NOT WORK HERE
pros: Free food sometimes, nice people, free parking.
cons:
The cons outweigh the pros, no contest. Upper management likes to micromanage the most insignificant issues, yet when we really need them to address critical problems- they're nowhere to be found; they leave you to fend for yourself despite the complete LACK of control that you're given of the situations. Not to mention, there is a lot of "finger pointing".

Large communication gaps amongst departments, and misaligning goals. 

Awful culture, not going to change anytime soon. Behind the times by light years. You're not given a voice on decisions that will directly impact your daily job, management is aware of that, yet they are doing nothing but dangling empty promises to your face. They give false hope to keep naive people, those who know better see right through it. 

Lastly, antiquated systems. If you want to be a top contributor in the supply chain world, you cannot cut corners. Learn to invest in world class softwares like other companies. Outdated systems make the job needlessly complex for employees who have to use it everyday. Actually, the whole department specializes in unnecessarily complicated procedures, efficiency is not their forte. Companies with strong supply chains do not NEED have to multiple systems just to keep up with demand.

review_title: Excellent Opportunity and Company to work for!  No Regrets
pros: I've been with the company just over a year now.  Just after I started with teh company, they opened a WFH policy, which is different for each department, but it has open a major door for flexibility and a Work/life balance.  The Pay and compensation is competitive for the market and the flexibility (outside of month end close) has been beyond fair.  Compensation, with all things considered, is more than just the pay, and the compensation, (benefits, pay, flexibility including WFH and flex time) have been great.  I see the company frequently promotes from within, so there are numerous Growth Opportunities, or opportunities to learn new things, although the opportunities to move up the "corporate ladder" are not abundant, but there are many opportunities to move in different directions.
cons:
Long hours during month end close
Bi-Monthly Payroll.
Long hiring process... My hiring process took just over 2 months from the time that I interviewed to the day that I started.  Part of the delay was the merger that had recently taken place, additionally, there was a tiered process that required steps that had to be completed before the hire date was granted...

cons: Everything from the people who works there to management.  The company is a complete joke.  They hire based on who you know, rather than work experience and background.  The sales team is full of egotistical and self absorbed people with "zero" background in sales.  You are automatically promoted to sales within 9 months of being hired, even if you have no clue of the industry you are working in, just because you are personal friends with management. I question that??? Talking about sales, they treat the project managers like garbage.  They give you demands rather than ask you to do something.  It must be nice to work once a week and when you in the office, just yap all day and treat the project managers like servants.  Management will smile in your face and then put a sword in your back. If they "like" you then great you have a job for life, but if you are a good worker but not their favorite then you can get let go at any given time. The best advice I can give is to constantly suck up to management, laugh at their obnoxious and lame jokes and you will be just fine.

review_title: Very intense-nerve wracking environment - Its a shame.
pros: Pay is decent and I have met some great people.  In my plant, the management team seems to be giving their all to make positive changes for the better.  You can see that they really want to treat you like a human being.  Getting your job threatened will no longer phase you because you will become numb to it pretty quickly.
cons: The "captain of the ship" seems to be working against my boss and his fellow managers.  These guys want positive change but are being belittled and humiliated on a daily basis and in front of the hourly employees and seem to be afraid to make any decisions anymore.  It is apparent when captain walks out on the prod. floor - the managers literally cower.  Machines are overbooked and that seems to be ok with the captain.  You will be told a 5 day/week plant...say goodby to your family and friends, kid's birthdays etc...you will be scheduled to work.

pros: The pay is pretty good, the work can be interesting
cons: Typical corporate style of management. Decisions on the company are made outside of local management, like choice of machinery etc.  So not much is suited to purpose, maintenance is very scarce and machinery is encouraged to run as fast as possible, so it breaks down often. Workforce is 'encouraged' to work harder based on weekly output figures, hopeless of course and does nothing to aid production and morale. Production planning is very hectic and disorganised so jobs are either rushed, late or messed up. I do feel management hide a lot of facts from employees and think they dont find out.

pros:
Massive company with plenty of opportunities to move around and grow your career. Their is a culture of personal growth and attention on employee satisfaction and engagement.

Leadership has a clear vision and strategy. Works hard to ensure everyone has an opportunity to understand it if they're willing to put forth the effort to listen. CEO is very down to earth and loves talking with employees from all parts of the business and genuinely listens to their feedback.

Big focus on continuous improvement and growth. Always looking forward. 

Benefits are pretty standard (401k, Employee Stock Purchase, HSA health plan, standard vacation, bonus program for qualifying positions).
cons:
Again, massive company with a lot of moving pieces. Sometimes takes a long time to get things done. A lot of people get involved in every project. Can get hectic and frustrating.

Large divide between corporate office employees and plant/mill employees. They live in separate worlds.

review_title: Great Company Overall though position is one of the most difficult.
job_title: Production Planner in North Charleston, SC
pros: Job security. The Charleston plant had a great year financially in 2010 due mostly to their asphalt products. The company has great benefits.
cons: The Production Planner position in the Chemical division is one of the most difficult positions to have. You are on call 24/7/365. Balancing work and personal life is very difficult. The pay does not reflect the number of hours worked each week. Oftentimes, as a planner, you are seen as the enemy because you can't satisfy everyone's expectations. Too much responsibly is put on the planner's shoulders. You are setup to fail. All of this has been communicated to upper management. Though they acknowledge it and agree, they don't plan to correct the situation. This position has a huge impact on other departments (including getting the final product to the customer when promised).

pros:
- management are quite flexible so you can take holiday hours here and there.
 However this is due to change come Jan 2020. Holiday will have to be taken at set periods in the year, half days will not be allowed unless exceptional circumstances 
- lots of overtime (but only if you work on shop floor) 
- good place to get in / learn basics / improve cv
cons:
- average to poor salary in comparison to similar jobs elsewhere 
- no benefit package (no sick pay, no paternity/maternity, no schemes to join, no bonus available) 
- training and development is non existent 
- travel is expected rather than asked but this isn’t mentioned at interview stage
- very sleezy upper management which makes any female under the age of 30 very uncomfortable 
- management stuck in their ways 
- moral here is dreadful, EVERYONE wants to leave, even the most positive people are brought down

pros:
Extremely ethical senior management team
Good benefits and Good work environment
Overall a good group of employees
Those with more than 5 years with MWV are generally very proud of where they work
CEO has a vision that seems to be working, unfortunately he is the only one who knows where we are going (this is a pro and a con)
Hard work is often rewarded - but you have to be sure your work is known
cons:
Vision of senior management not communicated clearly (lost of words but not a lot of specific  information)
Dead wood floats to the top too often
Lots of personnel churn breads uneasiness in the workforce, however if you are self directed you will be fine
Many new hire have a 'what's in it for me' attitude and do not seek to contribute to the big picture and longevity of the company

review_title: It's what you make of it
pros: Lots of great opportunities if you know how to promote and speak up for yourself.  They make a lot of great, interesting products and are quite driven to be the best.  Beautiful work environment with a great culture.  Cafeteria, gym, coffee shop, free parking.  The people are really wonderful.  If you put a lot of effort into working here and you get involved (i.e., networking), you'll probably enjoy it.  There are a lot of opportunities for personal career development.
cons: You must know how to play the "corporate game" to get ahead and have to know people, instead of just work very hard.  HR is absolutely useless, with the exception of probably two people.  Pay is only middle-of-the-road, among similarly sized companies.  Recent layoffs were devastating to several departments and there are a lot of rumors about the future of the company.

review_title: Quick growth and positive changes in slow change industry
pros:
Things are not static for long at WestRock,  there have been HQ moves, acquisitions,  closures, restructuring, etc etc in a short time.

CEO has done a good job of growing the company quickly and skillfully to compete with some of the bigger names in the industry, hoping to top them one day.

Management has always been pretty good.

Home Office has allowed jeans, and work from home days, matching trends of what has happened in other industries, although lagging behind the trend.
cons:
With the attempt to catch the bigger fish in the company they have tightened pay raises and hiring.

Not a lot of extra incentives to work for the company or stay.  Employees who reach 30 years pretty much get the same piece of paper as an employee who reaches 5

review_title: Great Place - Supply Chain - Duluth GA
pros: Company has grown at a very rapid pace over the last 10 years and does a good job with the difficult task of integrating new businesses.  Good people, strong leadership, and engaging place to work.  The company is spending a lot of time and effort on employee engagement and it shows how interested they are in employee development and employee happiness - this is a great effort.  They have made many changes lately that show they are willing to listen to feedback and make meaningful changes that positively impact employees.  Flexible work schedules, employee development, supply chain university continuing education, networking events, etc.  It is great stuff!
cons: Sometimes the work can be hectic with competing priorities and the rapid pace of the business, but that is the case in most supply chain organizations.  Otherwise, outside of the normal challenges of supply chain jobs, good place to work.

job_title: Heavy Equipment Operator in Atlanta, GA
pros: Since the merge it seems management is listening and trying harder to create a better working environment. Plenty of overtime. Management and coworkers are helpful. Management at this facility is understanding about life issues and time needed.
cons: Poor communication too often. Pay is nowhere close to competitive with this position! Have to work as a temp for far too long for consideration for fulltime employment. (correlation with-) Extremely high turnover rate. Common since approach is often not utilized. Advise from workers is almost non-existent. Harsh work environment, nature of the beast in this line of work, especially for temps. If you're the best at what you do, forget advancement. Company says they cannot allocate for higher raises (average raise @1.5%\yr) while the CEO totaled over $12,000,000/yr recently.

review_title: Nice company, hard to become a permanent employee
pros: Great work environment at every office, very flexible, employees are pretty nice. Great benefits for people that are actually "EMPLOYED", cool employee perks like discounts at certain stores and restaurants and entertainment. Many employee socials sponsored by different companies throughout the year.
cons:
WestRock has almost the same amount of contractors as they do employees. To actually become a permanent employee from a contract position is nearly impossible now, it's ridiculous and crazy because it actually cost less to employ people permanently than it does to hire contractors. 

Salary does start of low but as you do great work your pay will usually increase. 

It's also very hard for minorities to move up. There is a handful of minorities holding management positions. We just got our first African American woman vice president. I guess they took notice of some complaints. Let's see if we get anymore diversity among the hire-ups.

review_title: Decent pay but not without the overtime.
pros: Not micromanaged too bad. Climate controlled warehouse. I like my direct supervisor.  Good benefits company matches 5% 401k. Payed holidays. Overall a decent place to work.  Good team atmosphere.
cons: Minimum to zero chances for advancement, even if they know that you are overqualified at your position there just aren't a lot of opportunities.  management can up and tell you that you are working the weekend on a Friday and they do not care about your personal time.  It seems as though they already know who they are going to hire before they post a job.  The pay is okay but not without the overtime.  I'm pretty sure they base your pay knowing that you're going to get overtime and that's not the way it should work.

pros: They have a lot of structure, well organized, well prepared, have a lot of trainings, and looks very clean and safe,  this factory  use to be mess, but,  the actual general manager gives to MWV a very proficient foward. And i was witness of that growt...
cons: The managers lost their passion, they usually give orders on the desk but they rarelly go outside their offices, they looks that they are ok with the actual results, no coaching (motivation)to the lower hierarchical levels, as I see there is a lot of waist called talent in this factory. I think Its time to take advance of that and use the skills of their people. The other thing is that is very dificult to access to a another level in the company. Is why I left the company.

review_title: Inefficient procedures and departments...good ole boy system
pros: Benefits such as health and bonus, community service
cons: Specifically: Operations Center in Charleston, SC. Southern good ol' boy system, you have Papa Bear and his little cubs (puppies) pointing fingers and blaming other departments. If you don't hunt, fish, brown nose or bring Papa Bear information then you will not get promoted or even stay long. Working environment is strenuous and it doesn't promote team work. It starts with leadership and works its way down to long term employees who brown nose to keep their job instead of doing their jobs well.

pros: NOTHING. 11 PAID HOLIDAYS
cons: FILTHY PLACE.BENEFITS.PAY.MICRO-MANAGING EMPLYEES.VERY LONG HOURS 50+/WEEK 6 DAYS/WEEK FOR 45 WEEKS OUT OF 52 MINIMUM.

job_title: Maintenance Mechanic in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Pay is ok for the title, consistent work, not much is expected of you. Large employer that makes it easy to blend in and not get noticed if that’s your goal.
cons: Difficult to move up, not a place if you desire progress. Management culture is us versus them. No real Leadership just buzz words and slogans. The maintance superintendent is a nice guy but lacks social skills when it comes to leading his department. It can be frustrating when you see a solution to a problem and it’s overlooked because of not having a degree. Most people seem to be in a rut that work here.

pros: Recent merger creates cost syngery $1B by 2018, but not human morale synergy. The new company is still trying to integrate all functions and in all locations.  Hope they will keep R&D, innovation and design for the long haul. Work/life balance is good at least in our department. All my colleagues are talented, hard working and want to make a different in their career and company future.
cons: Cost synergy also costs employee morale - whether already left and stay for now. At least two rounds of layoffs in Richmond office in last two years are not motivating. The senior upper management seems not be able to communicate corporate results and  with Wall Street analysts. Every time they spoke, stock dropped. Well, it's been dropping like a water fall from $62 to$ 45 for the last 6 months.

review_title: Great pay to entice living in the area
pros: Get to be very self-directed, there are many opportunities for improvement, it is easy to move up, and relative to the industry there is still a lot of investment in this facility.
cons: Little to no formal training, if in production there is no work/life balance, it is almost impossible to get anything to change (culture,) there are a lot of responsibilities that are out of your control, would not assume getting a bonus (has trouble meeting goals,) Union can be difficult to work with and the supervisors came up through the union making it more difficult.

pros: the pay is pretty competitve
cons:
Management is disrespectful in following workers around and constantly complaining and threatening job along with working in the worst environment ever as far as a 100 degree plant.  Nit picking management style. Noise environment is deafening and you cannot hear each other.  No training for new employees.. Wont follow safety guidelines. 
Medical Insurance is not the best.

review_title: Good place, but undergoing a lot of change
pros: The people are generally nice, and Richmond VA is a good place to live.  Also, we are moving into a brand new office building, next to a river, with pleasant walking trails to a adjacent island.
cons: We are going through a lot of changes in the central office right now.  The whole accounting and administration function is being outsourced to Manila, and the IT functions will soon be outsourced to India.  Morale is pretty low among affected employees, and it is not good even among employees who will not be directly affected.

review_title: IT CIO is missing the mark
pros: Lots of exciting things are happening in IT with digital transformation and many other projects which provides lots of learning opportunities to people.  Many people work extremely hard to make the organization successful.
cons: Great leaders have been let go for really bad reasons and to hide HR mistakes.  And really bad leaders are still in their positions.  The CIO needs to dig deep and find out what is really happening...he is losing lots of good people because they miss their strong leaders and don't want to work for the ones in place now.  Little to no work/life balance and poor HR support.

review_title: Good starting salary but limited growth from there on
pros: Initial incoming pay is good if you negotiate properly and the projects are engaging.  Select management will develop you and your career but its not uniform across the system.
cons: The merger and subsequent reorg. within the Corporate Procurement department have caused a mass exodus among employees flocking to other companies with no back-fill of their old positions.  Don't expect to get more than a 2% raise your over year regardless of your contribution.  Its HR policy, even with a grade level increase through promotion not to increase your salary by more than 6%.  The best way to increase your salary once you work at WestRock is to leave for a year or two and come back.

job_title: Machine Helper in North Tonawanda, NY
pros: A decent job for someone with little or no education. If you have any college you might as well run because they look down upon it. Or any education past high school for that matter
cons: The management likes to try and seem smart when in fact all they know is what their boss tells them. No original thinking at all, if you try to come up with new faster my efficient ways of doing things they will be shot down no matter what. I work in the plant in north Tonawanda and the management there likes to preach safety, however they don't really care about the safety of their employees at all.

review_title: Overall the  pay is not worth it
pros: The pay with a factory is always decent, and this was no different here.
cons:
-The hours are an expected con, but the major problems with the plant I worked at were leadership related. This could change over time, so it could evolve into a place worth working at. 
-1st Shift gets all of the glory, while leaders and workers in the other shifts are only looked at by what the computers tell them.

review_title: Legal Department Is Not Nice Place to Work
pros: Overall decent place to work, clients are friendly, smart and usually willing to work with you. Salaries are OK. Benefits are good.  Free parking which is unusual for downtown Richmond. Nice cafeteria and gym onsite.
cons: The management of the Legal Department are old fashioned, bad communicators and there are very few good managers.  It has the feel of a Northeastern Law firm where hierarchy reigns, resistance to change is high and problems are ignored (if you don't like it here just leave). They talk a good game for being inclusive and concerned about making it a good place to work but they are so in their box and just satisfied with the fact that the work is getting done.  The reality is that most people, not all, are overworked and very unhappy and but for the bad economy of the last several years turn-over in this department would have been much higher.

pros: Overall this a very decent company to work for.  People generally stay there for quite a long time (older employees were offered a pension which I think has helped with the tremendous employee retention). The people there tend to be friendly, competent, and dedicated to doing the best work they can do for their clients, which is rare and refreshing. People there really seem to care about what they are doing. The Norcross campus is about a half mile from downtown Norcross, which offers lots of lunch choices and a pleasant place to walk if you have the chance to get out during lunchtime. Unlike a lot of other companies, it's not a madhouse trying to get in and out of the parking lot at the end of the day. In the Norcross campus, most people have HUGE offices and plenty of space, which helps keep people from getting sick at work. At least in my department, the work pace is very manageable and rarely stressful.  It's rare that I work late nights or weekends.  The company has made huge jumps in growth in the past 8 years, first buying Smurfit Stone in 2011, then merging with MeadWestvaco to become the second biggest packaging manufacturers in the country.  The work is interesting, and can even be fun and rewarding.
cons:
Shareholder value is the overwhelming focus at the company, which means that employee incentives, particularly raises, take a backseat to earning money for the board and the shareholders.  While this is not unusual at many businesses, the eventual result is that there is very little incentive for most employees to work harder, learn new things, take on new responsibilities, etc. The pay is not exceptional, from what I understand it is moderate to low.  We do get yearly raises, but generally the average is probably around 2.5%. Don't think you can lowball offer your way into the company and then get a significantly better salary after you've proven yourself. Despite expanding my position's responsibilities significantly, adjusted for inflation, I only make slightly more than the day I was hired.  As far as I can tell there is no way around this wall, people say that the low raises are HR policy that is independent of employee achievement. This, coupled with the long tenure of many older employees, means that it is hard to advance and easy to stagnate there.  You may have a pleasant work life and a good boss, but you'll never get promoted or get a raise unless someone just decides to quit (which rarely happens because of the pension) gets fired (which also rarely happens) or retires. 

The health benefits packaging started off fairly standard but it gets worse every year.  As it stands now there is only one plan choice with a deductible of several thousand dollars that has to be paid yearly before anything else is covered (apart from preventative physicals and such). Great if you shatter your femur, not so much if you have bronchitis or sprain your ankle.  The company does offer an HSA that they'll contribute to as a way to help offset the cost of the deductible, so that does help a little. 

The retirement plan has a good match (it actually increased a point after the merger) but they've changed where it is held three times in the last five years, which means you don't always have a lot of choice of the funds you'd like to put into your retirement account.         

Compared with companies that my peers work for, WestRock's benefits and vacation time are quite low.  2 weeks vacation only for the first 5 years, then 3 weeks years 5-12, 4 weeks 12-18, etc. When I was first hired the 20 days of vacation mark was at year 10, but recently they have been quietly moving it up a few years, presumably as a cost cutting measure in the hopes that people will leave before they reach that point. It's a little disheartening, I think if you've been with a company a decade you should get (and need) more vacation time than that.    

The company offers no maternity leave, no on site gym, no daycare.  The feeling I get is that the company is still very much in the old school mode of "shouldn't your wife be handling that?" when it comes to child care. The company conducts random drug tests at all levels, not only for a prescreen, but at any time. They appear to be ramping this up lately.

review_title: Excellent Place to Work - Lots of Advancement
pros: Excellent Leadership from the new General Manager. He's really working to change the culture from the previous failed administration. There are programs in place that are focused on continuous improvement and making the company better all-around.
cons: The plant is located in the middle of nowhere. Many of the employees end up driving from nearby large cities.

review_title: Good pay and people, poor culture and management
pros: Flexibility, pay, many good people/coworkers who care.
cons: Environment is greatly dependent on the site you work out. The culture could be amazing while other sites have done of the worst culture. Consistency between management is lacking creating unclear expectations. The “good ol boy” system is alive and well. True diversity and inclusion is lacking. None of the sites I worked with could grasp the changing workforce and need to change recruitment and engagement strategies. Attendance policies are outdated.

review_title: A good company with great potential
job_title: Packaging Sales Representative in Richmond, VA
pros: MeadWestvaco corporation is a stable company with a strong balance sheet.  The employee base is diverse and skilled, and it has done a good job at reengineering it'self to become a global leader in end-to-end packaging solutions.  The company stresses their code of conduct, respect for the individual, and results based objectives in order to create economic profit for the employees and shareholders.
cons: During the economic downturn, mid-senior level managers are primarily interested in their own business performace, rather than mentoring mid-career executives and working with cross function SBU's to align on strategy as one MWV.  Competition between executives seems professional yet many times we're competing with each other in the marketplace.

pros:
Pay is competitive and salaries generally trend toward the median range of the bell curve for a position range.  

Benefits are competitive as well.

Co-workers are well-rounded, educated and great to work with.
cons:
Performance review process is not well administered by management.

Management does not understand what motivates employees.

Travel expectations can be exhausting, and the travel&expense policy and its supporting team are not very sensitive to those who travel often.

pros: The company was just acquired by Westrock, with all the new locations there are more opportunities to move and grow within the company.
cons: If you are an hourly employee the point system is something I think is ridiculous. It requires you to be precisely on time when arriving and leaving work. When it was slow I completed my work and helped out other employees in my area, and if I would have left work early I would have received a half a point against me even though I went above and beyond to complete my tasks and to help out my team.

pros: When I started there it was "THEE" place to work in our small town, and it was just MEAD.  It was hard physical work but it came with good pay and great benefits.  There was a great working atmosphere. I liked my job.  Then they merged with Westvaco and it became just a job. After 20 years I left, I had become just a number, making about the same money I made 20 yrs before.
cons: They pay you just enough to keep you, and they do not care about personally it is all about the bottom line.  And I am not sure they can find the bottom line.  So not only did I feel under appreciated I felt I worked for a company with no heart.

pros: Very few pros and too many cons. They only pro is the pay, especially after 60 days. But only if you can last that long
cons: Too many to list, instead of putting you where you will thrive. Had a resume with years of experience in forklifts and they put me on this god awful machine. Made 20k boxes an hour and if they boxes aren't stacked fast, perfect, and tagged you are in trouble. Barely any training. And to top it off you only get a 20 min break! That includes lunch. Not very diverse and they don't even give you a second chance. Got fired in 3 weeks because someone else stacked the. Boxes wrong and of course it was all my fault! Terrible place to work, was told it was a good time to be there by the employees, never saw that.

review_title: Stuck in the 1950's?  Westrock is too!
pros: Nice downtown office building in easy to commute to location.  Environmentally friendly office.  Secure location next to Federal Reserve.
cons: With the recent merger between RockTenn and MWV - this company has solidified itself as a dinosaur.  Zero diversity present, and some hostility to women in the workforce at this company (yes, really).  Old, white, southern men are 90% of management.  Employees have been culled and key areas of development are being minimized.  This company is now just a shell of it's former self - a few floors of the whole Westrock building.  Other dinosaurs like Westrock went extinct decades ago - this one is not long for Richmond.

pros: The 98 hour weekly paychecks you can't spend.
cons:
HR looks hard for reasons to fire you until she can.  Zero missed time policy.
Up to 98 hours worked in 7 days..all the time.  Unsafe.  Not a woman's job. Back breaking and exhausting.

review_title: Don't Work Here Unless You Enjoy Cliques and No Advancemenet
pros: Nothing good to say about the company
cons: Management cliques, No room for growth, training is a joke, huge gap between office and production floor, management doesn't treat employees fairly, dishonest about advancement, doesn't see everyone equally, I could go on for days about all the negatives

pros: Good Pay. And it’s every week.
cons: Too much computer training and not enough hands on training. You learn by doing the job not sitting behind a computer a part of your day reading and testing. We took a test to get in the company, now you have to take more tests that take you away from your hands on training. Where’s the logic in that?

pros:
Reasonable compensation
Competitive benefits- 401K, Insurance, etc...
While I did not work in manufacturing there was a high priority put on safety
cons: Employer had unreasonable and unclear expectations. Job description was not reflective of actual position. Little to no training was provided in order to aid in development.  The career path was quite unclear, which coincided with poor management styles. While I worked with many great people, the culture is antiquated for a company that is attempting to innovate and bring in top talent. Overall I was disappointed with my experience at the company. The negative environment, lack of direction, and overall political nature created a space that left morale low and an sense of being undervalued as an employee.

review_title: Exciting and rewarding place to work if you can resist politics
pros: Great company with way to many cool places and projects to work on. The entire paper making process is exciting and amazing. Every type of equipment you can imagine and every type of job you could ever imagine exists at this company. Challenging, exciting, fun, endless opportunities.
cons: Too many levels of management. Some departments like HR may be a little bit over-sized. Policy should be reviewed more frequently so that good sense business takes precedence.

pros: MWV Specialty Chemicals has been a great place to work because they truly invest in their employees.  The leadership team promotes ownership of work and gives appropriate levels of authority to allow employees to grow and develop.  There is a lot of effort put into developing  strong teams and common goals.  There is also very strong adherence to ideals of safety, ethics, and environmental compliance.
cons: As with any large company, there are occasional bureaucracy headaches that must be managed.  The focus on IT (computer systems, software, and support) leaves something to be desired.
